sentences: Nikolaos Arvanitidis (Greek: Νικόλαος  Αρβανιτίδης; 21 August 1976), better known by his stage name Nikos Vertis (Greek: Νίκος Βέρτης) is a popular Greek singer.
section: N/A

sentences: He was born in Gorinchem, Netherlands and his origin is from Galipsos village, near Kavala.
section: N/A

sentences: To date, he has released five studio albums along with one CD single, and two special edition CD/DVD albums.
section: N/A

== Career == | === Early life ===

sentences: Early life =
section: == Career == | === Early life ===
== Career == | === Early life ===

sentences: The son of Argyris Arvanitidis and Morfoula Arvanitidi, at the age of six, Vertis and his family moved to Thessaloniki, Greece and at seven, he started playing the Bouzouki.
section: == Career == | === Early life ===

sentences: By the age of 15, he started getting involved with singing.
section: == Career == | === Early life ===

sentences: At age 16, he moved back to the Netherlands for two years, where he attended a technical high school.
section: == Career == | === Early life ===

sentences: He returned to Greece for his military duties, and once completed started getting involved with his love of singing.
section: == Career == | === Early life ===

sentences: He started singing in small clubs in Thessaloniki and other locations around the region of Macedonia.
section: == Career == | === Early life ===

sentences: In the summer of 2002, he started singing at the popular club "Rodon" where he made a big impact, and continued singing there until summer 2003.
section: == Career == | === Early life ===
== Career == | === 2003-2004: Poli Apotoma Vradiazei & Pame Psihi Mou ===

sentences: 2003-2004: Poli Apotoma Vradiazei & Pame Psihi Mou =
section: == Career == | === 2003-2004: Poli Apotoma Vradiazei & Pame Psihi Mou ===
== Career == | === 2003-2004: Poli Apotoma Vradiazei & Pame Psihi Mou ===

sentences: In 2003, Vertis signed with Universal Music Greece and released his debut album titled Poli Apotoma Vradiazei (Night comes too fast).
section: == Career == | === 2003-2004: Poli Apotoma Vradiazei & Pame Psihi Mou ===

sentences: The songs "Asteri Mou", "An Feigeis", "San Trelos Se Agapao" and the title track "Poli Apotoma Vradiazei" became radio hits in a short time, while Peggy Zina lent her voice for two duets on the album titled "Eimaste Horia" and "Hanomaste" which were also radio hits.
section: == Career == | === 2003-2004: Poli Apotoma Vradiazei & Pame Psihi Mou ===

sentences: For the winter season of 2003-2004, Vertis moved to Athens, Greece where he collaborated with Peggy Zina at club Apollon.
section: == Career == | === 2003-2004: Poli Apotoma Vradiazei & Pame Psihi Mou ===

sentences: At the third annual "Arion Awards" in 2003, Vertis won the award for "Best New Artist".
section: == Career == | === 2003-2004: Poli Apotoma Vradiazei & Pame Psihi Mou ===

sentences: In May 2004, Vertis started singing at club "Rodon" in Thessaloniki again, in successful shows until August.
section: == Career == | === 2003-2004: Poli Apotoma Vradiazei & Pame Psihi Mou ===

sentences: In September 2004, he released his second album Pame Psihi Mou (Lets go my soul) with songs by Giorgos Theofanos.
section: == Career == | === 2003-2004: Poli Apotoma Vradiazei & Pame Psihi Mou ===

sentences: The songs "Pos Tolmas", "Thimamai", and "Se Mena" become radio hits.
section: == Career == | === 2003-2004: Poli Apotoma Vradiazei & Pame Psihi Mou ===

sentences: At the same time, Vertis started performing at club "Posidonio" for the winter season of 2004-2005.
section: == Career == | === 2003-2004: Poli Apotoma Vradiazei & Pame Psihi Mou ===

sentences: His performances at "Posidonio" were highly successfully, with some calling him "The next big Laiko singer".
section: == Career == | === 2003-2004: Poli Apotoma Vradiazei & Pame Psihi Mou ===

sentences: At the fourth annual "Arion Music Awards" in 2004, Vertis was nominated in the category "Best Male Laiko Singer".
section: == Career == | === 2003-2004: Poli Apotoma Vradiazei & Pame Psihi Mou ===
== Career == | === 2005-2006: Pes To Mou Ksana & Pos Pernao Ta Vradia Monos ===

sentences: Pes To Mou Ksana & Pos Pernao Ta Vradia Monos ===
section: == Career == | === 2005-2006: Pes To Mou Ksana & Pos Pernao Ta Vradia Monos ===

sentences: In the spring of 2005, he started his second round of performances at club "Posidonio" where he remained for the whole summer.
section: == Career == | === 2005-2006: Pes To Mou Ksana & Pos Pernao Ta Vradia Monos ===

sentences: In the summer of 2005, he released his first CD single titled "Pes To Mou Ksana" (Tell me again), which was certified Platinum and awarded the "Best-selling Greek Single of the Year" at the fifth Arion Awards.
section: == Career == | === 2005-2006: Pes To Mou Ksana & Pos Pernao Ta Vradia Monos ===

sentences: For the winter season 2005-2006 he continued singing at club Posidonio.
section: == Career == | === 2005-2006: Pes To Mou Ksana & Pos Pernao Ta Vradia Monos ===

sentences: In December 2005, Vertis released his third album, "Pos Perno Ta Vradia Monos" (How I pass the evenings alone).
section: == Career == | === 2005-2006: Pes To Mou Ksana & Pos Pernao Ta Vradia Monos ===

sentences: The CD featured music by Kiriakos Papadopoulos with lyrics by Ilias Filippou.
section: == Career == | === 2005-2006: Pes To Mou Ksana & Pos Pernao Ta Vradia Monos ===

sentences: The album was quickly certified Platinum, while the songs "Pes To Mou Ksana", "Poia Esu", "Pos Na To Exigiso", "Den Se Niazei", and "Kapote Tha Deis" become radio hits.
section: == Career == | === 2005-2006: Pes To Mou Ksana & Pos Pernao Ta Vradia Monos ===

sentences: In the beginning of 2006, Vertis re-released the album as a special edition with a bonus DVD featuring seven music videos.
section: == Career == | === 2005-2006: Pes To Mou Ksana & Pos Pernao Ta Vradia Monos ===
== Career == | === 2007–present: Mono Gia Sena and Ola Einai Edo ===

sentences: 2007–present: Mono Gia Sena and Ola Einai Edo =
section: == Career == | === 2007–present: Mono Gia Sena and Ola Einai Edo ===
== Career == | === 2007–present: Mono Gia Sena and Ola Einai Edo ===

sentences: For the winter season of 2006-2007, Vertis sang again at club "Posidonion".
section: == Career == | === 2007–present: Mono Gia Sena and Ola Einai Edo ===

sentences: In March, he started recording his fourth studio album, titled Mono Gia Sena (Only for you), which was released in April 2007 and included a bonus DVD.
section: == Career == | === 2007–present: Mono Gia Sena and Ola Einai Edo ===

sentences: From the album, the songs "Mono Gia Sena", "Matia Mou Glyka", "Parapono Mou", "Svista Ola" and "De M'Agapas" became instant radio hits and charted throughout the summer.
section: == Career == | === 2007–present: Mono Gia Sena and Ola Einai Edo ===

sentences: In July 2007, the album was certified platinum, and became double platinum by February 2008.
section: == Career == | === 2007–present: Mono Gia Sena and Ola Einai Edo ===

sentences: For the winter season of 2007-2008, Vertis sang for the fourth year in a row at club "Posidonion", ending on 14 January 2008.
section: == Career == | === 2007–present: Mono Gia Sena and Ola Einai Edo ===

sentences: The final night was filled with guest appearances by fellow singers and friends such as Antonis Remos, George Dalaras, Antonis Vardis, and other celebrities.
section: == Career == | === 2007–present: Mono Gia Sena and Ola Einai Edo ===

sentences: In October 2008, Vertis began a world tour of twenty concerts in Australia, Israel, the United States, Canada, and Europe, ending on 17 January 2009 at the HMV Hammersmith Apollo in London.
section: == Career == | === 2007–present: Mono Gia Sena and Ola Einai Edo ===

sentences: Vertis' fifth studio album Ola Einai Edo (Everything is here) was originally announced to be a February 2009 release, but was finally released in early April.
section: == Career == | === 2007–present: Mono Gia Sena and Ola Einai Edo ===

sentences: The twelve-track album was written by Christos Nikolopoulos, Antonis Vardis, and Dimitris Dekos.
section: == Career == | === 2007–present: Mono Gia Sena and Ola Einai Edo ===

sentences: It was released in three versions: a standard twelve-track album in a jewel case, an edition in a rectangular box with a bonus "Mega-Mix" CD of thirteen of Vertis' greatest hits, and a version that includes a magazine.
section: == Career == | === 2007–present: Mono Gia Sena and Ola Einai Edo ===

sentences: As part of Universal Music's promotional campaign, a digipak edition with a fixed price of €9.90 was also released, notable for being about half of what the average new album is priced at in the Greek market.
section: == Career == | === 2007–present: Mono Gia Sena and Ola Einai Edo ===

sentences: The first single "Den Teliosame" was released to radios in early April and is an erotic ballad; a music video was created and was directed by Giorgos Gabalos.
section: == Career == | === 2007–present: Mono Gia Sena and Ola Einai Edo ===

sentences: The album was certified Platinum quickly, and later certified 4× Platinum.
section: == Career == | === 2007–present: Mono Gia Sena and Ola Einai Edo ===
